Subject: Would you do a crossword for $120?
Message_body:
[

Hi Friend, We're looking for someone to fill a job role testing and reviewing crossword apps and all kinds of other word, number and puzzle games on their phone or tablet. So, do you like relaxing on a Sunday afternoon with a crossword puzzle? Then this job could be right up your street - and it pays very well too. Here are the detailsâ€¦ Job title: Pocket hundreds of dollars every day testing and reviewing crossword and other word, number and puzzle apps on your phone or tablet Job description: Crosswords, sudoku, match-3: there are a lot of old-school word, number and puzzle games that have been adapted to the digital world via apps. And the small companies creating these apps need some eagle-eyed remote workers to take their new apps for a spin and give them feedback. Don't worry, you don't need to be genius crossword player, you just need to spot bugs and give honest feedback on your experience using their apps. Pay: $30 an hour (minimum $120 a day) Click here https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/ee519oldn0212/track-url/gf989o3ca4b95/ff656ec0dd8d0ecd0f09041bb7cc3660765df7c9 to apply for the position Friend. Location: As this is an online position, it's open to people from any country, so you already qualify on that front! Requirements: You'll need to meet the standard requirements for online work. Namely, a smartphone or tablet, an internet connection and a minimum of 4 available hours each week to do the work. The hours are flexible, so it's up to you when and how much time you put in, but 4 hours a week is the minimum. You could do 4 hours a day if you like (or more), which will net you about $120 a day. Necessary experience: As I say, you don't need to be a crossword genius or anything like that. This is mainly about testing the usability of the apps, so checking whether there are any bugs, if they run smoothly or lag, that kind of thing. So the only experience you need is a keen eye and the enthusiasm to help small companies improve their apps. We'll provide you with full training on the best way to write up your reviews. Subject: [The freeCodeCamp Forum] Summary
Message_body:
[

A brief summary of [The freeCodeCamp Forum][1] since your last visit on August 12, 2018 2871 New Topics 1 Unread Messages 921 New Users -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ### Popular Topics [Retrying for a position I got rejected for][2] What a surprise! I do get the attraction, and peeps need jobs, and whatever, go for it if you want. But the whole thing is like an illustrative example in some pamphlet deriding “The Evils of Capitalism”, it’s almost comical. It smells so bad, everything you’ve said is a red flag -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- [Scope / Async / Await Issues][3] :))) look again on your local storage. That line of code is using the radius as a name(key) and the array of objects as a value. On click you save radius and the last loaded values. Basically you will end up in local storage with two entries. For example: One for radius “radius”= 5555; Another one for values “5555” = [{value: 1}, {value: 2 } … and so on]. On load later on, if you got the radius and if there is a collection equal with radius you render on the screen that collection. On next click you save input again: One for radius “radius”= 1000; Another one for values “1000” = [{value: 555}, {value:333 } … and so on]. Makes sense? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- [Tribute Page - Nikola Tesla Again][4] Looks pretty good, there isn’t much to comment on. On the body you are setting padding-top: 20px but then overwriting it later by setting padding: 10px. I would just keep the top padding and also remove the default margin from the body. You might try using the vw unit for the width on #main instead of %, that way it will adapt to the screen size. You can also do that for the padding on #tribute-info Another option is to give the #tribute-info content a container and setting a max-width on it. This will let you control the paragraph length a bit better.

...content
.container { max-width: 720px; margin: auto; } I would move the inline CSS from the footer paragraph to the CSS. Good job. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- [No contact so far, I need criticism!][5] A lot of different things I’m noticing across your portfolio site, resume, and LinkedIn profile. I’ll start with the LinkedIn profile because it’s what HR/recruiters tend to look at first. LinkedIn: You need to network to increase your number of connections. A lot of recruiters/companies look at that number and will judge you for it. Your first goal should be to get to 50+. “I have skills in frontend web development languages such as JavaScript, jQuery, HTML/CSS, and Git version control” is unfortunately not very impressive. You need to do more than that to land a job these days—have you learned Angular, React, or Vue yet? There just aren’t many jobs that will realistically demand only those skills. Your About section needs to be either more impressive, or more unique. As it is now, your About section could just as easily be written by someone else. Is “Spring Codes” a company? If not, change that to something else. JavaScript, HTML, and CSS are not front-end frameworks—maybe you me... -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- [Learning Python for interview questions?][6] Recently I saw a video of a guy saying Python was probably the best language to perform in interview questions thanks for being the less verbose + other things. I know a little bit of Python when I started leaning Data science (did it for about a month and a half) but mainly where I know to do stuff is in JS Do you think it could be justified to finish learning python enough to do interview questions? (I would be doing from now on also all practice interview questions in Python obviously) Or maybe don´t and just stick to Javascript? (I gotta say I kind of hate JS syntax a little bit and I liked a lot more Python simplicity) -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ### Popular Posts raisedadead - [Why is Forum Dark Theme no longer working?][7] Just got this fixed. I moved the custom styles to a git repo this morning and aparently the export and the import did break for one hex code. Sorry about the inconvenience. Thanks for reporting. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- kevinSmith - [Overwhelmed and struggling without support][8] Getting a job is hard. It takes a while. And don’t feel bad if you weren’t perfect on the interview - on the job I landed, I certainly wasn’t “perfect”. And even if you did everything right you can still not get the job. Yes, it is very frustrating. If you need to take a little time off, then do it. Get a new perspective. I also recommend a doc I wrote up on my tips on finding a job, here. And learning on your own can be lonely. Try to find meetups or Facebook groups in your area. It was very encouraging to talk with other people struggling like I was. And I even got a few job leads. Best of luck. Take care of yourself, and don’t give up. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Marmiz - [Rest Operator with Function Parameters Help][9] This is something that was addressed and talked a lot, and hopefully will be smoothed out in future updates of the curriculum. If it may be of any confort, I’m of the opinion that this is the part where the “true” learning begins, having to roll up the sleeves and do your own researches. It’s hard, perhaps tedious, but rewarding. Anyway back to the point. Instead of explaining line by line, I’ll try to give you an example so maybe you can see the reasoning behind the code. Imagine we are working on our company code and we have a function to sum two numbers const sum = (a,b) => a + b; Nothing fancy. One day, Steve is asked to update a page and add a new input. But forget to update the sum function. // since Steve added another input this is the function that gets called sum(1, 10, 200) // 11 Wait. Steve expected sum to return 211. So he comes to you and ask if you can rework your function to accept any number of parameters, so none has to worry about your sum function ever ag... -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- holhen - [Why for loops behave this way if it have another one inside it!][10] The inner loop goes through 1-4 every time the outer is incremented. First i becomes 0 and j goes through 1-4 in 4 steps. Then i is incremented, j goes through again 4 times and it continues until outer cycle ends. This is how nested for loops work. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- **New for you** * [Simon Game project finished][11] - 3 - [Project Feedback] * [Survey Form | Your feedback please][12] - 4 - [Project Feedback] * [How to use data stored in mongodb as initial state for Redux Reducer][13] - 4 - [General] * [Tuesday Meetings][14] - 9 - [Chicago] * [Where is useful or better than ul the dl dd dt tags][15] - 5 - [HTML-CSS] [1]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/ [2]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/retrying-for-a-position-i-got-rejected-for/288610 [3]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/scope-async-await-issues/288621 [4]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/tribute-page-nikola-tesla-again/288608 [5]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/no-contact-so-far-i-need-criticism/288598 [6]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/learning-python-for-interview-questions/288529 [7]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/why-is-forum-dark-theme-no-longer-working/287647 [8]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/overwhelmed-and-struggling-without-support/287775 [9]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/rest-operator-with-function-parameters-help/287914 [10]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/why-for-loops-behave-this-way-if-it-have-another-one-inside-it/286522 [11]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/simon-game-project-finished/288636 [12]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/survey-form-your-feedback-please/288525 [13]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/how-to-use-data-stored-in-mongodb-as-initial-state-for-redux-reducer/288732 [14]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/tuesday-meetings/288629 [15]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/where-is-useful-or-better-than-ul-the-dl-dd-dt-tags/288625 This summary is sent from [The freeCodeCamp Forum][1] when we haven't seen you in a while. Change [your email settings][16], or [click here][17] to unsubscribe. Because that's exactly what today's job offersâ€¦ Job title: Receive a daily paycheck for testing and reviewing reading apps like the Kindle app on your mobile or tablet Job description: Whether you read every book in the charts or you have a single favourite you return to again and again, you could be right for the reading app tester and reviewer job space we're looking to fill today. Thanks to the rise of tablets and smartphones, reading apps like Kindle's app and Whatpadd are hugely popular and we're looking for five people to test and write online reviews for these apps. You don't need to read books all the way through, just take notes of your general experience and write that up into a short review. That said, we're mostly interested in reviewing reading apps that focus on books written in English, so you'll need a firm grasp of the language. Requirements: As mentioned above, a grasp of the English language will be beneficial! Apart from that, a phone or tablet to test the apps on (and write your reviews on), an internet connection and an enthusiasm for books wouldn't go amiss either! The job has flexible hours, up to 10 a day (which could pay around $300). Experience necessary: We'd love it if you are the world's keenest reader and have experience reading books on your tablet or phone. But really that experience isn't necessary, it's just a bonus. What we really need is someone who's comfortable dedicating a few hours a day to thoroughly testing these reading apps and relating their honest experience, good or bad. Subject: $210 a day to train your brain
Message_body:
[

Hi Ahsan, Would you like to get smarter? And would you like to receive money at the same time? If you're nodding YES to both of those questions, then you're going to love today's job offeringâ€¦ this is your chance to earn some extra capital by testing and reviewing brain training apps like Memorando! Job title: Get smarter and earn extra bucks testing and reviewing brain training apps like Memorando on your tablet or phone Job description: Studies have shown that brain training can improve working memory and increase intelligence. And we're looking for 5 people to put the best brain training apps, like Memorando, out there to the test. You just need to download and play around with the apps and then write up your opinions on your experience. You'll make some extra cash and, who knows, you could even get smarter in the process! In all seriousness, all you need is a tablet or phone, an internet connection and 7 hours available each week to test these apps out. Experience: This isn't brain surgery. Message_body:
[

Hi Ahsan, Do you remember reading comic books as a kid? Cheering for Batman fighting against the Joker, or for Wonder Woman knocking out some generic thugs? Those were the days! Subject: Wait, isn't it Tuesday? ps: Learn C++ is complete!
Message_body:
[

If you canâ€™t see this email - View it in your browser. ( http://track.customer.io/deliveries/RM-kAgMAAWr_V7nhOb3-8W8HzTXEeg== ) Â  Â  Â  Â  Codecademy ( https://www.codecademy.com?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_05_28_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=top_logo ) Log In ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_05_28_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=top_login_button ) Â  Â  Monday Course Drop ( https://www.codecademy.com/catalog/subject/all?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_05_28_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=header_img ) Â  Â  New Lessons in Learn C++ ( https://www.codecademy.com/courses/learn-c-plus-plus?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_05_28_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=top_cta )! Â  Itâ€™s been six months since we released C++ and your interest blew us out of the water: over 250,000 learners have enrolled in our Learn C++ course! Today, we are happy to announce that Learn C++ is now complete with two brand new units. The first unit, Classes and Objects, focuses on defining data types and how to build more scalable code while the second unit, References and Pointers, dives into memory allocation and how it can improve overall code performance. Â  We also added more content to the Functions unit: a lesson on scope and flexibility and a code challenge to practice using different types of functions and flexibility within C++. Â  To top it all off, we interviewed Simon Brand (they/them), a C++ expert and Developer Advocate for Microsoft. They are an active member of the international C++ community: proposing new standards and frequently speaking at conferences about the latest developments within C++. Below is an abbreviated version of our interview with them. To see it all, check out our blog post ( https://news.codecademy.com/simon-brand-c-plus-plus/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_05_28_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )! Â  Â  Â  SimonSimon Brand, Developer Advocate Â  What drew you into C++? Â  I kind of fell into C++ by accident. At university, I was doing some compiler work for [OpenCL], which is a language for programming accelerators, like GPUs, DSPs, specialized hardware â€” one programming model for all of them. Working with those compilers, the C++ decision was kind of made for me and I got interested in it and got a job in a very similar kind of field. So I was still doing C++ and the interest in it kind of just grew from there. I started reading blogs, watching videos of conference talks, and decided I wanted to write my own blogs and get involved in the standard process and start talking at conferences myself. So it just grew from there. Â  Â  Where do you see C++ heading in the future? Â  I think in terms of where it will go in the industry, I think it will continue to develop in the embedded space, which has pretty much been owned by C for the longest time. But I think as developers in that space try and look elsewhere, or more young people get involved in the community and have context for what's going on in other languages, people will start to look at things like C++ or Rust for embedded development more. And I think it will still be growing. From the data that I see, it's still growing in adoption across the board as well. So it will continue to be used in the financial industry and in video games and all the places where it's currently a market leader. Â  Â  Â  With our latest update, it's never been a better time to start learning C++. Â  Start Now ( https://www.codecademy.com/courses/learn-c-plus-plus?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_05_28_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ) Â  Bonus Video: How to Think Like a Programmer ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rWMuEIcdJP4 ) ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Programmers are often mythologized as superheroes that can solve any type of problem put in front of them with just a few keystrokes. The reality is that most programmers have a particular mindset and approach to solving problems that helps them get to a desirable outcome. In this video we break down that mindsetâ€”so you can start thinking like a programmer too. Follow Along ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rWMuEIcdJP4 ) Â  In case you missed it on our blog: ---------------------------------- * Livestream: Getting Started with C++ ( https://news.codecademy.com/getting-started-with-c-plus-plus-livestream/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_05_28_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ). * How to Build a Data Science Portfolio ( https://news.codecademy.com/how-to-build-a-data-science-portfolio/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_05_28_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ). * What are Neural Networks? ðŸ§  ( https://news.codecademy.com/what-are-neural-networks/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_05_28_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ). Â  Happy Coding, Codecademy Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  codecademy ( https://www.codecademy.com?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_05_28_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=bottom_logo ) Â  Copyright Â© Codecademy. All rights reserved. Â  Our mailing address is: 575 Broadway, 5th Floor New York City, NY 10012, USA Â  Unsubscribe ( http://track.customer.io/unsubscribe/RM-kAgMAAWr_V7nhOb3-8W8HzTXEeg== )

Subject: [The freeCodeCamp Forum] Summary
Message_body:
[

A brief summary of [The freeCodeCamp Forum][1] since your last visit on August 12, 2018 325 New Topics 1 Unread Messages 1452 New Posts -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ### Popular Topics [I started one year ago and just landed my first job as a Software Engineer!][2] I can’t believe I am typing this right now. I put the title in and got one of the best rushes of my life. I lost my job as a graphic designer and was almost sick of the industry and decided to look at other options. I couldn’t go back to college (I dropped out my first year to help my mother and family), and I was 27 last year. I couldn’t find the time nor money to go back, but I didn’t have a degree. I looked into EMS, then Firefighter, or operating a power plant, anything to get me into a field to get paid and support my family and get my life back together. I pooled up all my money, sold things I had, and came across coding as an option without a degree. Freecodecamp someone mentioned and I thought it sounded neat. I began to study for 3 months on FCC for at least 5 hours a day and struggled like hell with Javascript (really, really struggled). During the 3rd month I found out about bootcamps, and enrolled in a 6mo. program. I hadn’t any idea what to expect, but I was surrounded by... -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- [Dude, just stay focused!][3] I have seen so many topics on the forum about people asking what programming language they should learn or what framework they should learn in order to get a job. They always refers to what is “hot” in the CS market right now. I see a lot of responses saying they should learn a certain language or frameworks in order to get a job. To be honest, this causes the person learning to code to jump from technology to technology. That is not good because you are in a learning phase. No matter what framework or language you learn, there will be a place for you in the computer industry. Just sit down and learn something to the point to where you are very comfortable. That will make learning other technologies easier. Like I have said before, ignore the hype when learning to code and stay focused on what you are currently learning at the moment. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- [Applied to 25-30 jobs over 1month and no responses: what am I doing wrong?][4] Hello freeCodeCamp, I have been applying to around 25-30 jobs since early april and I have not received any responses. I understand that the job search is very difficult and that I shouldn’t expect a job this quickly but I was also advised to get feedback on my resume and portfolio update them every month or so instead of applying to hundreds of jobs without feedback. This is actually my second attempt at applying: I had started to apply in mid February of this year and landed an email response within a few weeks, but was ghosted after a non-technical skype interview. I panicked and stopped the job search to learn new technologies such as MySQL and redux, build another fullstack project, and revise my resume before starting my current job search. So my problem is that my skillset and portfolio are better than they had been when I first applied (as in I have more projects and skills under my resume) and I fixed some serious bugs in my personal projects yet I have received even few... -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- [Personal Portfolio - project feedback :-)][5] Hi all, I finally got around to making a start on the personal portfolio project - it’s super basic at the moment but I’d really appreciate any feedback! https://codepen.io/greenoid/full/wbrpGO Many thanks in advance, Simon -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- [Survey form-feedback][6] Hi @Gizo, it looks good. However, revisit the user stories. Right now you’re passing 15/17. If you notice clicking your Submit button does nothing. The error will tell you why and is and easy fix. same with the error regarding your radio buttons use the fieldset element around your checkboxes too. They’ll flow together a lot nicer like your radio buttons -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ### Popular Posts michaelhenderson - [Dude, just stay focused!][7] I am glad you all like the article. I know what it is like just starting out when trying to learn to code. It can be frustrated staying focused. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- clevadani - [Dude, just stay focused!][8] Good piece of advice bro. I know how confusing it is when you’re starting out as a developer. There are lots of options and lots of factors that will influence what you should be learning. My advice to beginners is to go with FCC’s stack. And if you’re not too comfortable with javascript, explore other languages. But the most important part is sticking with one language and persisting with it. Don’t start jumping from one language to the next. The idea is to get comfortable with programming. Your target should be consistency and not trying to learn every single “hot” language out there. Once you pick up one, understanding another programming language will be easier. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- owel - [Dude, just stay focused!][9] Languages come and go. No matter how you think X language is too popular or too big to fail, it will get obsolete someday, or sooner. (think about Cobol, Fortran, Pascal, Basic, so on and on, etc) Instead learn the fundamentals of programming, computational thinking, data structures, algorithms. These will always be applicable, no matter the computer language. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- shimphillip - [I started one year ago and just landed my first job as a Software Engineer!][10] Congratulations! Your github timeline looks amazing :slight_smile: -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Oliver_Olivier - [Dude, just stay focused!][11] In other words, turn off the noise and hard work and focus. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- **New for you** * [Looking for critique on my CV and personal page that I'm going to apply for jobs with][12] - 10 - [Getting a Developer Job] * [MongoDB and Mongoose - version in package.json][13] - 41 - [Data] * [Tribute page - first project ever][14] - 11 - [Project Feedback] * [How can I get multiple variables from a function in javascript][15] - 16 - [JavaScript] * [Can i host my projects anywhere other than codepen][16] - 18 - [Project Feedback] [1]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/ [2]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/i-started-one-year-ago-and-just-landed-my-first-job-as-a-software-engineer/278622 [3]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/dude-just-stay-focused/278531 [4]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/applied-to-25-30-jobs-over-1month-and-no-responses-what-am-i-doing-wrong/278617 [5]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/personal-portfolio-project-feedback/278586 [6]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/survey-form-feedback/278580 [7]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/dude-just-stay-focused/278531 [8]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/dude-just-stay-focused/278531 [9]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/dude-just-stay-focused/278531 [10]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/i-started-one-year-ago-and-just-landed-my-first-job-as-a-software-engineer/278622 [11]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/dude-just-stay-focused/278531 [12]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/looking-for-critique-on-my-cv-and-personal-page-that-im-going-to-apply-for-jobs-with/278806 [13]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/mongodb-and-mongoose-version-in-package-json/278634 [14]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/tribute-page-first-project-ever/278498 [15]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/how-can-i-get-multiple-variables-from-a-function-in-javascript/278792 [16]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/can-i-host-my-projects-anywhere-other-than-codepen/279506 This summary is sent from [The freeCodeCamp Forum][1] when we haven't seen you in a while. Change [your email settings][17], or [click here][18] to unsubscribe. [17]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/my/preferences/emails [18]: https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/email/unsubscribe/664c2d93c6cdd04c31de585c087cb6fa535994a34e2b9beb709e31e6ecc190e0

]

Subject: FREE guide: Review apps for $35 an hour
Message_body:
[

Follow these four simple steps to write the ultimate app review...Hi, Here's a question I receive a lot... _"I want to earn an income reviewing apps online, but I'm not a very good writer so I don't know how to write reviews...what do I do??"_ The answer is simple… You follow the simple four-step app reviewing guide I've prepared for you. Then you'll be ready to earn $35 an hour from remote app reviewing jobs like this one. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/bg8912elw199a/track-url/ep4445gftzdaa/9bf61e3d0a751f387c724af2e95f407adf7101ff Here we go... Step #1: Test the app out! Well, yes, you actually need to try out the app you're going to review! That's the first step. Once you've downloaded the app, you don't need to approach it like a scientist analysing a new chemical compound. Just spend a little time trying it out and getting to grips with it. See how it works, whether it does what it says on the tin, whether it's got any handy bonus features. Have a play around and have fun exploring it! And while you do that... Step #2: Jot your opinions down on a piece of paper as you go Yep, grab a paper and pen and make some notes as you test the app out. You can think about things like... Do you like it? Is it helpful to you? Will you keep it on your phone after you've finished trying it out, or delete it straight away? If you'll keep it, why? If you'll delete it, why? You don't need to write a novel here. The point is to just jot down your main thoughts, feelings and observations about the app. This is one of the keys for landing remote app reviewing jobs like this one. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/bg8912elw199a/track-url/ep4445gftzdaa/9bf61e3d0a751f387c724af2e95f407adf7101ff Then we move onto the next step... Step #3: Turn your notes into a simple three-part story Next, you take your notes and you make a short narrative out of them. Again, we're not writing a novel here, but we can apply a simple novel-like structure to your review… Beginning. Middle. End. In the beginning of your review you introduce the app. You write about what it promises to do, its features, whether it's free or costs a little money, that kind of thing. Next comes the middle. This is where you relate your experience with the app. Look back at your notes from the previous step and cram all of your observations into this part. It's a simple copy and paste job really. Then we get to the end section of your review. Here you sum up your feelings about the app and whether you'd recommend it to other people. Pretty simple, right? And only one more step to go... Step #4: Post your review… and collect your reward! This is the final step. You've tried the app, made your notes, turned those notes into a review (with a beginning, middle and end), and now you're ready to share it with the world. So, you post your review where the job tells you to and then… You receive your reward! How much will you get? Well, it depends on the job, but remote app reviewing jobs like this one give you $35 an hour. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/bg8912elw199a/track-url/ep4445gftzdaa/9bf61e3d0a751f387c724af2e95f407adf7101ff In fact, if you're interested in what I've been talking about today, I think that job is the perfect place to start. You only need a spare five hours a week… You can do it from anywhere in the world… And with the four-step guide I've provided you with today, you can get a review written in no time at all. So, don't hang about… Start reviewing apps for $35 an hour now. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/bg8912elw199a/track-url/ep4445gftzdaa/9bf61e3d0a751f387c724af2e95f407adf7101ff Best wishes, Simon Sultana Paid Social Media Jobs 244 Madison Avenue New York City 10016-2817 United States To unsubscribe, click here https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/bg8912elw199a/track-url/ep4445gftzdaa/2a434a54ea8dae1d239f7e25f25046e9849fc186.

]

Again, we're not writing a novel here, but we can apply a simple novel-like structure to your review… Beginning. Middle. End. In the beginning of your review you introduce the app. You write about what it promises to do, its features, whether it's free or costs a little money, that kind of thing. Next comes the middle. Subject: Meet Hollywood’s secret movie millionaires
Message_body:
[

They’re earning millions and no one’s even heard of them...Hi, Did you catch Avengers: Infinity War last year? It was gripping end-of-the-world stuff… Hell, even Spiderman dies at the end (whoops, sorry if that was a spoiler!). A lot of people LOVED that movie... It grossed a whopping $678 million. Which just goes to show how much money is floating around the movie industry... Right now, the industry is worth about $43 bn a year and it's only predicted to grow even more over the next five years. Point is a lot of people are cashing in big time on these flicks. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/bv998kon0rfea/track-url/ep4445gftzdaa/167011cea12eba6895aeee215045f1dc4a619ece That should come as no surprise… I mean, we all know where a lot of that money goes… A-list actors pick up an average of $15-$20 million for big hitter roles… while even small roles bag them $1.5-$4.5 million... Movie directors receive anything from $128,790 up into the millions for their efforts... And the rest of the cast, the extras, the crew, the production team, and so on, get their bite of the action too… But here's something you might not realise… There's actually a whole class of people in the movie industry who are pocketing huge amounts of money on every new flick released… https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/bv998kon0rfea/track-url/ep4445gftzdaa/167011cea12eba6895aeee215045f1dc4a619ece and they have NOTHING to do with making the films… They don't star in any movies… they don't help produce them… and they don't even sell them... What these guys basically do is sit on their laurels wherever they happen to be in the world, tap a few keys on their laptop and… hey presto, they've secured themselves a little swag bag of movie industry cash. Who the hell am I talking about? Movie Critics! I mean, here's a taste of just how much dollar these people are earning… YouTube star, Alonso Duralde, has pocketed $1,000,000 making movie reviews online... 55-year-old A. O. Scott has earned $1,000,000 as The New York Times go-to movie critic... New Yorker, Armond White, has made $2,000,000 writing some seriously controversial movie reviews... Impressive figures, right? I mean, imagine receiving thousands, even millions of pounds to watch your favourite movies... https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/bv998kon0rfea/track-url/ep4445gftzdaa/167011cea12eba6895aeee215045f1dc4a619ece Or, hell, to publicly bash the ones you hate! Sure, these guys are at the top of their game… Average movie critic salaries are estimated to be around $82,000 a year... Which might not sound like too much at first, but then you consider… You can do this anywhere in the world… It probably takes about half an hour to an hour to write a review… Oh yeah… and you get to watch MOVIES for a living! Subject: Put time on YOUR side
Message_body:
[

It’s a skill ALL successful, rich people master... Hi, What's a skill ALL successful, rich people have that ordinary folk don't? Two words... Time management. As I've said before, the key to creating wealth is setting up multiple streams of wealth alongside your main source (which, in most people's cases, will be your day job). The thing with setting up extra streams of is that it takes time. And most people think they simply don't have any spare. Well, I've got some news for you… You DO have spare time to bag some extra cash… it's just hiding from you. Let's find it together today... First, to make the most of your time, the single most important thing you need to do is assess how you're currently spending it. To do this I'd recommend writing down everything you do for one day of the week. And I do mean everything... From the moment you wake up to the time you go to bed, make a note of how long it takes you to do the various things you do in the day. As you're doing this, try to include as much details as possible. For example, don't just write 'eight hours at work'... break it down by each main job that you do at work. And the same goes for your free time in the morning and evening too. Rather than 'one hour for breakfast', break it down: 5 minutes to prepare breakfast, 10 minutes to eat breakfast, 15 minutes watching CNN and so on. It may seem boring and a bit of a chore, but this is the only way that'll you'll be able to see clearly where you have time that you can free up or use more effectively. And you'll probably realise that you're wasting a fair bit of time on things that aren't really necessary and that time can be put to better use. Then, once you've got a detailed breakdown of how you've spent your day, you can begin to streamline your time and start using it more effectively. Obviously it will be different for everyone depending on what you do, what type of person you are and what your hobbies might be - but I'm certain that by analysing how you spend your time like this, you'll spot chances to get more out of your day. And that leads me to my second time management tip: work smarter, NOT harder… Now, as I say, managing your time doesn't mean you have to reorganise it so you're constantly working - you should always give yourself plenty of time to relax. But one way to manage your time and reduce wasted time is to make sure you do the right thing at the right time... For example, you should think about when you work best and most efficiently. And make sure you do the most important things at that time of day. For example, I work best in the morning. It's when I'm at my freshest after a good night's sleep and most mentally productive. Chances are: it's the same for you too. The morning is often when people are at their freshest, most alert and most productive. However, most people like to 'ease themselves in' to work and end up squandering the extra energy they have in the morning. That means that when they get to working in the afternoon they're often a lot more tired and can take much longer to do things. So, when looking over the itinerary that you made of your average day, consider how you could reorganize your tasks so that you do the bulk of your work in the morning when you'll be able to work faster and more efficiently. And when you do get down to doing the work you've set aside time for, make sure you focus entirely on the task in hand. Remove any distractions: turn off your phone, ignore emails and ask people not to disturb you. Make sure you dedicate yourself fully to the task at hand. You'll be suprised at how much you can achieve in a small space of time if you are truly focused. And that leads me to a question… It is really time you're lacking? It's time (get it!) to be honest with yourself… Is the thing holding you back really a lack of spare time? Or is it a lack of organisation? If it's the latter and you're ready to admit that and do something about it, I have something you might be interested in... But it does involve managing your time effectively. If you can rise to the challenge then the rewards are tremendous. You can do this from anywhere you have an internet connection… And it can bank you hundreds of dollars every single week… for very little work (especially if you're optimizing your time). If you think you can manage your time effectively... Then click here to see if you qualify now. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/tt691nzphgbb3/track-url/ep4445gftzdaa/0d9a0388ebee772c764ba5ea372c25e96ac1383f Best wishes, Simon Sultana To unsubscribe, click here. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/tt691nzphgbb3/track-url/ep4445gftzdaa/e3f3c29b25c7fcc1a97244466185a8f3c5505a38 Paid Social Media Jobs 244 Madison Avenue New York City 10016-2817 United States

]

Subject: Get fired, get rich
Message_body:
[

Why getting fired from your job is the best thing you can do... Hi, They say that getting pooped on by a bird is lucky. It's not. It's just disgusting. But sometimes being metaphorically "s**t on from a great height" can be the best thing that happens to you. It was certainly the best thing that happened to Mark Cuban, who went from being fired from his lowly sales assistant job to the billionaire he is today. Let me tell you his story… and show you how by implementing his number one lesson you could be up $840 by the end of this week… https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/bh259jgks5487/track-url/yd46128a1l645/a8b9159d6cb95a5fc06921cdce0416522c81bda8 Here we go… A promising start It's 1982 and 24 year-old Mark Cuban is relaxing with a beer at home, in the cramped three-bed flat he's currently sharing with five friends. He's in a great mood, as tomorrow he starts a brand new job. Fresh out of university he's been working in a bar, but now he finally has a chance to kick-start his career. It's with a local retail outlet called Your Business Software and even though the job is at the bottom of the ladder - his role is to "open the shop, serve the customers and sweep the floors" - it's his chance to get in to a 'proper' company. More importantly, it involves selling a product that Mark has started to become fascinated by: computers. Mark starts the next day, full of ambition. His goal is to become the perfect employee, impress his bosses and work his way up. For the next few months, Mark takes home and literally devours the user manual for every single product Your Business Software sells. And soon becomes the go-to guy in the store for customers confused about all this new-fangled technology. And that's when things really take off for Mark... With his now in-depth knowledge of how the products work, customers begin asking if he can help install the software in their offices and homes. For this he earns a consulting fee which he splits with the store - increasing both his salary and the company's' bottom line. Not only that, Mark starts bringing in more business by actively seeking out companies to buy their software - rather than just relying on footfall coming in to the store. You'd think that his bosses would be over the moon at having such a loyal, forward-thinking, productive employee. But instead of being rewarded for his entrepreneurial skills, he's punished… A brutal betrayal Things come to a head when he sets up a deal with a brand new customer, worth $15,000 - a pretty significant amount for a small-town company. The problem is that it's still Mark's job to open the store, but the only time the customer can meet is at 9am. He asks his boss if he can go and close the deal but (probably jealous that he was being outperformed by the new guy) his boss refuses, reminding Mark that it wasn't his job to close outbound sales but to open the shop. So Mark makes a decision that will change his life forever. He asks a co-worker to open the shop for him while he goes to close the deal and pick up the $15,000 cheque. He thinks that when his boss sees the cheque he'll be happy with Mark's decision and forgive him for disobeying his order. He isn't. He doesn't. Mark is unceremoniously fired - for showing initiative and making the company a whole heap of money. Sounds ludicrous, doesn't it? Mark was the model employee, working hard and trying his best to make the company a success. But what did he get for it: the sack. If that's not being "s**t on from a great height" I don't know what is. A lesson learned That day, Mark decided he'd never again work for someone else. Instead he started his own computer software sales and consulting firm company, Micro-Solutions. With no one to hold him back Mark put his talent for business in to full throttle and throughout the 1980s worked hard to build his business. And in 1990 he sold the company for a cool $6 million - more money than he'd ever seen in his life. But Mark was only just getting started… In 1995 he launched online communications company Audionet with university friend Todd Wagner - a company that took full advantage of an increasingly popular piece of technology: The Internet. Again, Mark's entrepreneurial skills worked their magic. Within four years Audionet (which had been renamed Broadcast.com in 1998) had over 300 employees and was sold to Yahoo for a massive $5.7 billion, in one of the biggest deals of the 'dotcom bubble' era. Since then Mark has spread his money over a number of successful investments… He owns the US basketball team Dallas Mavericks, and the film production and distribution companies Magnolia Pictures and Landmark Theatres. And, as part of his role as a shark on 'Shark Tank', has invested in over 80 startup businesses spanning sports, communication, media, retail and finance industries. He's now worth an estimated $3.2 billion. A hell of a lot of money. But I want you to remember where it all changed for Mark… Because that's where we find today's lesson to improve your own life. You see, it was when Mark decided to take his life into his own hands and "never again work for someone else" that things really took off for him. And that's the message I want you to take on board today… You will only reach true wealth liberation (and ultimately true happiness) if you have the guts to do things your way. Now, you're probably thinking that you can't just up and quit your job, you've got bills to pay! And you're right… I'm certainly not suggesting you go out and quit your job right away. But I am suggesting the first step towards being financially free is to develop more money-streams alongside your current job… Something like the $840 a week this flexible gig offers. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/bh259jgks5487/track-url/yd46128a1l645/a8b9159d6cb95a5fc06921cdce0416522c81bda8 Then, when you feel like you're earning enough to comfortably live on, you can take that next brave step and go all in on your dreams. That's exactly what I've done. I'm writing this from a trendy little cafe on the river Thames in the heart of London, England. I just fancied a little trip away for a few days to one of my favourite cities. And there's no reason you can't spontaneously do what you fancy when you're financially free too. Start by trying this $840 a week gig as your first step today. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/bh259jgks5487/track-url/yd46128a1l645/a8b9159d6cb95a5fc06921cdce0416522c81bda8 Best wishes, Simon Sultana To unsubscribe, click here. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/bh259jgks5487/track-url/yd46128a1l645/c55f118fe30b9427bb6bce5817e24ba0b325de5c Social Sale Rep 244 Madison Avenue New York City 10016-2817 United States

]

Subject: Your first $100 writing royalty check

Subject: Become a YouTube millionaire in five years
Message_body:
[

Hi, You've got five years… To become a multi-millionaire. What do you think? Do you reckon it's possible? Probably not, right? But that's exactly what the person I'd like to tell you about today did... He went from university student to multi-millionaire and New York Times best-selling author in less than five years… All thanks to a home business you could start today. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/mc970jh8w30ad/track-url/ep4445gftzdaa/2c7c9bc1ff9f89bed30849b3925e7b7966b78f4e So who is this mystery millionaire? And how can you follow in his footsteps? Let me tell you his story... It's 29th April 2010 and Felix Kjellberg, from Gothenburg, Sweden is studying at the Chalmers University of Technology. He's a pretty clever kid, studying a degree in Industrial Economics and Technology Management. And he has a steady, relatively safe career path mapped out in front of him. He'll get a decent job, make a good wage and live a fairly typical middle-class life. There's only one problem… Like many of his generation, instead of spending his time studying, Felix spends most of his time hanging out with mates playing video games. But on the 29th April 2010, something important happens… something that changes Felix's life forever… He registers a YouTube channel with the username PewDiePie and posts a video he's recorded of himself playing a video game. Now, what has this all got to do with becoming a millionaire in five years? Well, Felix created his video because he'd recently become aware of a new social-media movement, called "Let's Play", where a growing number of gamers swap play-by-play videos of themselves playing a game. He believed the idea would take off and wanted to get in on the action. So he devoted more and more of his time to recording himself playing video games and kept sharing them on his YouTube channel. A year later, bored with his degree and seeing his YouTube channel start to gain some popularity, Felix made a pretty scary decision… Much to the shock and dismay of his parents, he dropped out of university and got a job at a hot dog stand in order to fund his new "career" playing video games. It was a risk… but it paid off, BIG TIME… By 11th July 2012 his YouTube channel reached one million subscribers… and the money from advertising really started to roll in - enough to quit his job at the hot dog stand and pursue his dream. Here it is in his word words: "To have that sudden realization that I could quit my job and just pursue YouTube… that was one of the greatest moments of my life." And the growth of his Youtube channel continues at a phenomenal rate… He now has over 92 million subscribers, his videos have received over 10 billion views and he has become a multimillionaire. In 2013 he banked around £2.8 million… in 2014 he added another £5.2 million... and in 2015 he earned a further £8.4 million... He's also topped Forbes' list of the richest YouTube stars and was included on Time's list of the 30 most influential people on the Internet. He's also released his first book entitled This Book Loves You, which went straight to the top of the New York Times bestseller list. And he's only 26. Felix's story is pretty remarkable, but he isn't the only one who has made a fortune from YouTube and other social media sites… There are hundreds of thousands of ordinary people across the world making healthy part or even fulltime incomes from social media websites like YouTube, Facebook and Twitter in all kinds of ways. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/mc970jh8w30ad/track-url/ep4445gftzdaa/2c7c9bc1ff9f89bed30849b3925e7b7966b78f4e And that's why I'm writing to you today… Because it's about time YOU got your foot in the door in this online social media goldmine… And I reckon, if you're just starting out, I've found the best way in for you... In fact, stay-at-home Mum, Annie Jones, has been using this social media goldmine to bag an extra $700 a week... https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/mc970jh8w30ad/track-url/ep4445gftzdaa/2c7c9bc1ff9f89bed30849b3925e7b7966b78f4e Click here to see how YOU can do the same. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/mc970jh8w30ad/track-url/ep4445gftzdaa/2c7c9bc1ff9f89bed30849b3925e7b7966b78f4e Best wishes, Simon Sultana To unsubscribe, click here. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/mc970jh8w30ad/track-url/ep4445gftzdaa/1dcae31306c427f91583a155f86aa8dd7f96c7a5 Paid Social Media Jobs 244 Madison Avenue New York City 10016-2817 United States

]

Subject: Linda quit… and made $25 million
Message_body:
[

Hi, Back in 2000, Linda Lightman had a respectable job as a labour and employment lawyer in New York. It paid well, but she still wasn't one for wasting money. So, when her teenage son had a clear-out of his old video games, instead of seeing them go in the bin, she decided to try selling them on eBay - just as an experiment to see what she could get. It was a decision that would change Linda's life forever… After seeing the games sell for a good return, she caught the eBay bug. But instead of selling more games, she turned to the real passion in her life for her next source of stock… high-end fashion. She raided her wardrobe and began listing all her unwanted clothes, shoes and handbags. She knew though that if she was going to make a good return on her stuff she'd have to do it properly, so she spent all her spare time learning how to take decent photos, writing detailed listings and doing plenty of market research to ensure that she'd priced her items at just the right price. It wasn't a chore though. In fact Linda loved it - it provided the perfect antithesis to her corporate day job. Her obsession with high-end fashion and a love of the clothes she was selling also helped. Her time and effort paid off as she started banking a healthy return from it - even making a mark up on some of the items. She soon ran out of her own things to sell. But that wasn't the end of the story… A couple of her friends, encouraged by her success but utterly clueless about how to sell on eBay themselves, started asking Linda to sell their unwanted stuff too - offering her a cut of the money made. Word soon spread about how good Linda was at selling and soon all of her friends and family were asking her to sell their stuff. It got to the point when almost every room in her house was filled with boxes of unwanted clothes waiting to be listed. It was becoming too big to just be a side project… so Linda made the decision to quit her day job and focus on growing her fledgling business - Linda's Stuff. The business model was simple. People would send her their unwanted high-end fashion items and she would photograph them, list them, and then ship them when sold. And she'd take a cut of the sale price (currently 62% of the selling price for items that sell for $999 and below, 75% for items that sell for $1,000 and above and 80% for items that sell for $5,000 and above.) as her fee. At first she ran her business from home and did all of the work herself. But as the amount of consignors (people who wanted Linda to sell their stuff) grew, it all eventually became too much for her to cope with alone - she had to hire in help. The business kept on growing (on eBay and beyond) and in 2006, she moved the business and its now 20 employees in to a 5,000-square-foot office space. She's moved offices several times then: first to a 12,000 square-foot office, then a 25,000-square-foot office and then finally to the 93,000 square-feet offices Linda's Stuff and its 100+ employees. Linda's Stuff now has about 140,000 items for sale and lists about 5,000 new items each day, making it one of the most successful online luxury consignment businesses in the world. In 17 years Linda has turned what was a little side-project, selling her unwanted clothes, in to a multi-million pound business - raking in over $25 million per year. She's wealthier than she could ever have been if she'd stayed in her job as an employment lawyer. Why am I telling you about Linda today? Because there's no reason YOU can't do the same. I'm not saying you need to start selling all your old stuff on eBay. Or even that you need to quit your job. I'm just saying that it's worth taking a chance to try something new every now and then. You never know where it might lead. Like this for instance… https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/at447b2s6za23/track-url/gf989o3ca4b95/3f70858146d6992ffcfefb796605181373333239 Where you can receive an extra $25k a year (minimum) doing something you're prob ALREADY doing. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/at447b2s6za23/track-url/gf989o3ca4b95/3f70858146d6992ffcfefb796605181373333239 Give it a try and… who knows… it could be the start of YOUR $25 million per year empire. Best wishes Simon Sultana To unsubscribe, click here. https://clicktrixmailer.com/index.php/campaigns/at447b2s6za23/track-url/gf989o3ca4b95/f1909fd9a9ef2be1c701558d731693db4071580a Paid Online Writing Jobs 244 Madison Avenue New York City 10016-2817 United States

]
